abstract.text: A view that displays a Live Photo—a picture that also includes motion and sound from the moments just before and after its capture.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use a Live Photo view to display the photo and control playback of its motion and sound content. In iOS and tvOS, you can obtain Live Photo objects from the Photos library, using the

classes, or by creating one from asset resources exported from a Photos library. In macOS, Live Photo objects are available only when editing Live Photo content in a photo editing extension that runs in the Photos app—see the
class to access Live Photo content in an editing session.

By default, a Live Photo view uses its own gesture recognizer to allow the user to play the motion and sound content of a Live Photo with the same interactions and visual effects seen in the Photos app. To customize this gesture recognizer—for example, to install it on a different view for proper event handling in your app’s view hierarchy—use the
To animate the view briefly to hint that a picture is a Live Photo, use the
This class displays Live Photos in native iOS and tvOS apps and macOS photo editing extensions. To display Live Photo content on the web, use the

abstract.text: Play Live Photos on the web.
Adopt the latest privacy enhancements to deliver advanced user-privacy controls.

doc://com.apple.photokit/documentation/P.title: Delivering an Enhanced Privacy Experience in Your Photos App

abstract.text: Provide the same interactive playback of Live Photos as in the iOS Photos app.
A representation of an image, video, or Live Photo in the Photos library.
A container that provides information about and access to the image, video, or Live Photo content of an asset to be edited.
An object that facilitates retrieving or generating preview thumbnails and asset data.
Present a person’s photo library using a picker interface, display Live Photos, or extend the Photos app with custom functionality.
Options for the semantic use and display style of icons for badging Live Photo assets, used by the
method.
A view that displays a Live Photo—a picture that also includes motion and sound from the moments just before and after its capture.
The audio gain to apply to the Live Photo’s movie content during playback.
The mode in which the view displays its content.
An object to be notified when Live Photo playback begins or ends.
A Boolean value that determines whether the view plays the audio content of its Live Photo.
The Live Photo displayed in the view.
Returns an icon image for the specified Live Photo semantic options.
A view for displaying Live Photo status.
A gesture recognizer that controls playback of the Live Photo in the view.
Begins playback of Live Photo content in the view.
Stops playback of a Live Photo.
Stops playback of a Live Photo in an animated manner.
The enumerated Live Photo content modes.
The
protocol describes messages sent by a

instance in response to playback events when playing the motion and sound content associated with a Live Photo. To receive these messages, implement the methods in this protocol in one of your controller objects and assign that object to the
property of a Live Photo view.
Options for how much of the motion and sound content of a Live Photo to play, used in the
method and in messages to the view’s
object.
Plays back only a brief section of the motion content of the Live Photo, without sound.
A view controller that provides the user interface for choosing assets from the photo library.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
